Ethnography is the description, interpretation, and analysis of a culture or social group, through field research in the natural environment of the group being studied. The main method of ethnographic research is thorough observation, where the researcher observes study participants over an extended period of time within the participants' own environment.[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-23)Comparative case studies have become more popular[[_when?_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")] in social science, policy, and education research. One approach encourages researchers to compare horizontally, vertically, and temporally.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-24)

At Harvard Law School In 1870, Christopher Columbus Langdell departed from the traditional lecture-and-notes approach to teaching contract law and began using cases pled before courts as the basis for class discussions

f.t:
An average, or typical case, is often not the richest in information. In clarifying lines of history and causation it is more useful to select subjects that offer an interesting, unusual or particularly revealing set of circumstances.[[_citation needed_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")] A case selection that is based on representativeness will seldom be able to produce these kinds of insights. When selecting a subject for a case study, researchers will therefore use information-oriented sampling, as opposed to [random sampling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_sampling "Random sampling"). [Outlier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outlier "Outlier") cases (that is, those which are extreme, deviant or atypical) reveal more information than the potentially representative case.[[_citation needed_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")] Alternatively, a case may be selected as a key case, chosen because of the inherent interest of the case or the circumstances surrounding it. Alternatively it may be chosen because of a researchers' in-depth local knowledge; where researchers have this local knowledge they are in a position to "soak and poke" as Fenno[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-7) puts it, and thereby to offer reasoned lines of explanation based on this rich knowledge of setting and circumstances.Four types of cases may thus be distinguished for selection:

1. Key cases
2. Outlier cases
3. Local knowledge cases
4. Comparative case studies.

b.t: Research in business disciplines is usually based on a positivist epistemology, [[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-14) namely, that reality is something that is objective and can be discovered and understood by a scientific examination of empirical evidence. But organizational behavior cannot always be easily reduced to simple tests that prove something to be true or false. Reality may be an objective thing, but it is understood and interpreted by people who, in turn, act upon it, and so critical realism [[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-15) which addresses the connection between the natural and social worlds is a useful basis for analyzing the environment of and events within an organization.Case studies in management are generally used to interpret strategies or relationships, to develop sets of “best practices”, or to analyze the external influences or the internal interactions of a firm. [[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-16) With several notable exceptions (i.e., Janis on Groupthink [[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-17)), they are rarely used to propose new theories.

At Harvard Law School In 1870, Christopher Columbus Langdell departed from the traditional lecture-and-notes approach to teaching contract law and began using cases pled before courts as the basis for class discussions [12]. By 1920, this practice had become the dominant pedagogical approach used by law schools in the United States [13]; it also was adopted by Harvard Business School.

Research in business disciplines is usually based on a positivist epistemology, [14] namely, that reality is something that is objective and can be discovered and understood by a scientific examination of empirical evidence. But organizational behavior cannot always be easily reduced to simple tests that prove something to be true or false. Reality may be an objective thing, but it is understood and interpreted by people who, in turn, act upon it, and so critical realism [15] which addresses the connection between the natural and social worlds is a useful basis for analyzing the environment of and events within an organization.

Case studies in management are generally used to interpret strategies or relationships, to develop sets of “best practices”, or to analyze the external influences or the internal interactions of a firm. [16] With several notable exceptions (i.e., Janis on Groupthink [17]), they are rarely used to propose new theories.

Other roots stem from the early 20th century, when researchers working in the disciplines of sociology, psychology, and anthropology began making case studies.[citation needed] In all these disciplines, case studies were an occasion for postulating new theories, as in the grounded-theory work of sociologists Barney Glaser (1930- ) and Anselm Strauss (1916-1996)

[Galileo Galilei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galileo_Galilei "Galileo Galilei") built his rejection of [Aristotle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle "Aristotle")'s law of gravity on a case study selected by information-oriented sampling and not by random sampling. The rejection consisted primarily of a conceptual experiment and later on of a practical one. These experiments, with the benefit of hindsight, are self-evident. Nevertheless, Aristotle's incorrect view of gravity had dominated scientific inquiry for nearly two thousand years before it was falsified. In his experimental thinking, Galileo reasoned as follows: if two objects with the same weight are released from the same height at the same time, they will hit the ground simultaneously, having fallen at the same speed. If the two objects are then stuck together into one, this object will have double the weight and will according to the Aristotelian view therefore fall faster than the two individual objects. This conclusion seemed contradictory to Galileo.

It is generally believed[[_by whom?_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")] that [Frederic Le Play](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederic_Le_Play "Frederic Le Play") first introduced the case-study method into social science in 1829 as a handmaiden to statistics in his studies of family budgets.[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-18)[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-19)Other roots stem from the early 20th century, when researchers working in the disciplines of sociology, psychology, and anthropology began making case studies.[[_citation needed_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")] In all these disciplines, case studies were an occasion for postulating new theories, as in the [grounded-theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grounded_theory "Grounded theory") work of sociologists [Barney Glaser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barney_Glaser "Barney Glaser") (1930- ) and [Anselm Strauss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anselm_Strauss "Anselm Strauss") (1916-1996).[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-20)The popularity of case studies in testing theories or hypotheses has developed only in recent decades.[[_citation needed_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")] One of the areas in which case studies have been gaining popularity is education and in particular educational evaluation.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-21)[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-22)Educators have used case studies as a teaching method and as part of [professional development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Professional_development "Professional development"), especially in [business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commerce "Commerce") and legal education. The [problem-based learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Problem-based_learning "Problem-based learning") (PBL) movement offers an example. When used in (non-business) education and professional development, case studies are often referred to[[_by whom?_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")] as _critical incidents_.[Ethnography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnography "Ethnography") exemplifies a type of case study, commonly found in communication case studies. Ethnography is the description, interpretation, and analysis of a culture or social group, through field research in the natural environment of the group being studied. The main method of ethnographic research is thorough observation, where the researcher observes study participants over an extended period of time within the participants' own environment.[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-23)Comparative case studies have become more popular[[_when?_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")] in social science, policy, and education research. One approach encourages researchers to compare horizontally, vertically, and temporally.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-24)
The [grounded-theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grounded_theory "Grounded theory") work of sociologists in the 20th century about case studies

s: These are primarily descriptive studies. They typically utilize one or two instances of an event to show the existing situation. Illustrative case studies serve primarily to make the unfamiliar familiar and to give readers a common language about the topic in question.

These are condensed case studies performed before implementing a large scale investigation. Their basic function is to help identify questions and select types of measurement prior to the main investigation. The primary pitfall of this type of study is that initial findings may seem convincing enough to be released prematurely as conclusions.

These serve to aggregate information from several sites collected at different times. The idea behind these studies is the collection of past studies will allow for greater generalization without additional cost or time being expended on new, possibly repetitive studies.

These examine one or more sites for either the purpose of examining a situation of unique interest with little to no interest in generalization, or to call into question or challenge a highly generalized or universal assertion. This method is useful for answering cause and effect questions.

b.t: Using case studies in research differs from their use in teaching, where they are commonly called [case methods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_method "Case method") and [casebook methods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Casebook_method "Casebook method"). Teaching case studies have been a highly popular pedagogical format in many fields ranging from business education to science education. [Harvard Business School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_Business_School "Harvard Business School") has possibly been a developer and user of teaching case studies.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-Garvin-25)[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-Ellet-26)Business school faculty generally develop case studies with particular learning objectives in mind. Additional relevant documentation, such as financial statements, time-lines, and short biographies, often referred to in the case study as exhibits, and multimedia supplements (such as video-recordings of interviews with the case subject) often accompany the case studies. Similarly, teaching case studies have become increasingly popular in science education. The National Center for Case Studies in Teaching Science[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-27) has made a growing body of case studies available for classroom use, for university as well as secondary school coursework.[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-28) Nevertheless, the principles in doing case study research contrast with those in doing case studies for teaching. Teaching case studies need not adhere strictly to the use of evidence, as they can be manipulated to satisfy educational needs. The generalizations from teaching case studies also may relate to pedagogical issues rather than the substance of the case being studied.Case studies are commonly used in [case competitions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_competition "Case competition") and interviews for consulting firms such as [McKinsey & Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McKinsey_%26_Company "McKinsey & Company"), [CEB Inc.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CEB_Inc. "CEB Inc.") and the [Boston Consulting Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Consulting_Group "Boston Consulting Group"), in which candidates are asked to develop the best solution for a case in an allotted time frame.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_study#cite_note-29)

b.t: An online retailer is poised for a 2nd wave of growth with transformed systems and processes

f.t:
e-Commerce companies are heavily dependent on robust systems that are scalable.  Order fulfillment is all the more crucial for our customer ([Giftcertificates.com](https://www.giftcertificates.com/)), who is into online gifting solutions characterized by seasonal demand peaks. 

As the systems are becoming unstable and unable to support the business and peak demands, we stepped in with an integrated approach that focused on site stabilization and total systems re-architecture using emerging technology solutions. We worked with the business and IT teams and executed the project in 3 streams

1. **Infrastructure:** Immediate peak season support, systems stabilization and infrastructure engineering
2. **Technology:** New technology architecture, application development and phased cut over to new systems
3. **Business Process:** Work flow enhancements and reducing offline steps in order processing

**The result was a sound back-end with scalable & efficient order processing, supporting multiple sales channels and the resultant business growth. **

​

Giftcertificates.com
Retail
Retail, eCommerce, Gifts, Technology Consulting, Re-engineering, Opti-shore, Order Processing
Project Main
Giftcertificates Platform Reengineering
Platform stabilization and re-engineering for an online retailer

**Solution Key Features**

1. Efficient Order processing in Order fulfillment system through parallel processing technology
2. Integration of the order placing web services for different sales channels
3. Adopted HA (High Availability) and HS (High Scalability) through application re-architecture based on the Message oriented Middleware
4. Streamlined deployment methodology enables easy rollback of new releases under unforeseen circumstances
5. Strike Iron web services – used for validating the US addresses. Makes sure the delivery is happening to the correct address
6. Data Center migration - Database shifted from Washington DC to Omaha with minimum down time
7. Localization and internationalization built into the application for easy roll out and to support different time zones, and different languages across geographies Enabled the MOM deployment to support large numbers of messages, users and applications across the extended enterprise
b.tp: Sales Channels, Order Processing and Back-office Modules

b.t:
**Recognize & Reward with the SuperCertificate REWARD from GiftCertificates.com**

Recognize and reward your employees or customers. Give the reward of choice with GiftCertificates.com. The SuperCertificate REWARD allows recipients to choose from over 200 nationwide merchant gift cards. That's the power of choice!

The co-founder of Retention Science, Jerry Jao, is an expert on using data, lots of data, to grow ecommerce revenues. Beyond that, he’s a gifted Taiwanese-born entrepreneur who proves what intelligence, hard work, and perseverance can accomplish. At Harvard Law School In 1870, Christopher Columbus Langdell departed from the traditional lecture-and-notes approach to teaching contract law and began using cases pled before courts as the basis for class discussions [12]. By 1920, this practice had become the dominant pedagogical approach used by law schools in the United States [13]; it also was adopted by Harvard Business School.

Research in business disciplines is usually based on a positivist epistemology, [14] namely, that reality is something that is objective and can be discovered and understood by a scientific examination of empirical evidence. But organizational behavior cannot always be easily reduced to simple tests that prove something to be true or false. Reality may be an objective thing, but it is understood and interpreted by people who, in turn, act upon it, and so critical realism [15] which addresses the connection between the natural and social worlds is a useful basis for analyzing the environment of and events within an organization.

Case studies in management are generally used to interpret strategies or relationships, to develop sets of “best practices”, or to analyze the external influences or the internal interactions of a firm. [16] With several notable exceptions (i.e., Janis on Groupthink [17]), they are rarely used to propose new theories.

Other roots stem from the early 20th century, when researchers working in the disciplines of sociology, psychology, and anthropology began making case studies.[citation needed] In all these disciplines, case studies were an occasion for postulating new theories, as in the grounded-theory work of sociologists Barney Glaser (1930- ) and Anselm Strauss (1916-1996)

e-Commerce companies are heavily dependent on robust systems that are scalable.  Order fulfillment is all the more crucial for our customer ([Giftcertificates.com](https://www.giftcertificates.com/)), who is into online gifting solutions characterized by seasonal demand peaks. 

As the systems are becoming unstable and unable to support the business and peak demands, we stepped in with an integrated approach that focused on site stabilization and total systems re-architecture using emerging technology solutions. We worked with the business and IT teams and executed the project in 3 streams

1. **Infrastructure:** Immediate peak season support, systems stabilization and infrastructure engineering
2. **Technology:** New technology architecture, application development and phased cut over to new systems
3. **Business Process:** Work flow enhancements and reducing offline steps in order processing

**The result was a sound back-end with scalable & efficient order processing, supporting multiple sales channels and the resultant business growth. **

b.t: A utilities company ushered in a new era of flexibility and efficiency in commercial operations

f.t:
**Nations start new eras with epic revolutions. Companies are not different, they too start new eras with epic programmes. **As with the nations, a single purpose of better future drives companies to take on massive initiatives involving 100s of people. This is the story of our client, National Grid Transco (NGT) who serves 40% of the UK’s energy needs piping natural gas for 21 million industrial, commercial and domestic consumers. 

Faced with the challenges of

- Legacy systems posing high risks
- Regulator enforcing quick changes
- Users expecting efficient systems

NGT made a decision to replace systems that support 2 critical functions of commercial operations- capacity auctioning and energy balancing. **While they were clear of the 'Why' & 'Where To', they needed a partner to define the 'What' & 'How To' (achieve the business goals with technology solutions). **

Wipro, one of the NGT's service providers with an 'emerging player' tag, joined the team of National Transmission and Trading (NT&T) division to start the 3+ year epic of Gemini (code named to represent 2 key business functions) from feasibility analysis to development and, periodic roll-out of over 15 sub-systems (2 sub-systems every 6 months). Together they equipped NGT to start the new era with

1. **Flexibility and Compliance:** Systems built on the ethos of component based design and configurable frameworks helped to reduce time of performing operations and time of implementing regulatory changes (e.g. new auctions implementation, billing rule changes etc.).
2. **Scalable Infrastructure:** OS & database servers deployment design helped to increase the system availability and security (e.g. redundant set-ups across geos, multi-level security)
3. **Stakeholder & User satisfaction:** Focus on user interface and inter and intra application interfaces served the variety of needs of the users (e.g. Shipper APIs, NGT systems integration, Goal based UI etc.)

More importantly, this success also laid a new foundation for the engagement between Wipro and NGT - **a shared vision of helping business with technology solutions and, a culture of persistence and innovation solving complex execution challenges**

b.t:
National Grid Transco plc (NGT) operates the high-voltage electricity transmission and natural gas transportation system in UK and the US (East). National Transmission and Trading (NT&T), NGT's department, manages and controls the physical and commercial aspects of the gas transmission system with a high speed network made up of around 175,000 miles of pipeline. This network supplies gas to 21 million industrial, commercial and domestic consumers, amounting to 40% of UK's energy needs. NT&T’s primary responsibilities include

1. Operating the network
2. Managing commercial activities
3. Providing data for the billing process
4. Maintaining the physical balance of the system
5. Buying or selling gas to counter daily supply and demand mismatches.

Capacity auctions & energy balancing systems replacement for a utilities company

Natural gas is fundamental to our way of life - we use it for cooking, heating, electricity and power. Over 90% of the natural gas used in Queensland comes from coal seams, but how is it formed and how is it produced? Take a look at how we go about developing our coal seam gas resources safely and sustainably, as we build a new industry that will power the Queensland economy for many years to come.

AT Link supports decision making for Energy Balancing, Exit capacity booking, Exit capacity Trading and Exit Capacity Invoicing. It interacts with various systems like SC 95, CSEPs, S & M, MO systems and Inv’95. AT Link generates Exit Capacity Invoices and Energy Balancing Invoices. AT Link is extensively used by Shippers, CVA, MO, Inter connector Agent and Storage operator in addition to System Operation and Billing users of Transco.
b.tp: AT Link - System for Energy Balancing

b.t: RGTA supports Entry Capacity Auctions, Capacity Constraint management, Entry Capacity Trade registration and produces Entry Capacity Invoices. It Interacts with CRAM for daily Auction capacity details and sends Invoices to Inv 95 systems, which in turn delivers the invoices to the Shippers. It has an interface to AT Link for Allocation details, which is used, in Invoicing.

**BUSINESS PROCESSES**

Gemini deals with the commercial operations of two important areas, Capacity and Energy Balancing of NT&T business operations. Business processes related to Capacity are Entry Capacity Auctions, Exit Capacity Booking, Capacity Constraint management, Capacity Trading and Capacity Invoicing. Business processes related to Energy are Decision making for Energy Balancing and Energy Balance Invoicing.

1. **Entry Capacity Auctions:** Entry Capacity is bought by the Shippers in the form of Firm or Interruptible capacity through Auction process. These Auctions are of various types like Short Term, Long Term or Buy-back.
2. **Exit Capacity Booking:** Exit Capacity is bought by the Shippers through direct booking of capacity.
3. **Capacity Trading:** Entry and Exit Capacity is traded among Shippers and the corresponding trade details are registered.
4. **Capacity Constraint Management:** In the event that the Sippers’ capacity requirements are not met, NT&T can apply constraints and remove all or part of Shipper allotments in accordance with the Shipper Contracts
5. **Capacity Invoicing:** Invoices are sent to the Shippers monthly according to the Entry and Exit Capacity allotments
6. **Energy Balancing:** Gas Balancing is key to the safe operation of transimission network. Shippers provide intended gas flow data (Nominations) at Input and Output points for Transco to plan the balancing operations of the transimission network. Once the gas is transmitted for the Shippers, balances are calculated for each shipper as the difference in the inputs and ourputs into/from the National Transmission System (NTS).
7. **Energy Balance Invoicing:** Invoices are sent to the Shippers based on the imbalances created in the network and based on the scheduling operations of the network.

​

**APPLICATION FRAMEWORKS**

“Capacity” and “Energy Balancing” business processes are grouped into logical business groups and abstracted as various Business Components, which can exist as indepent units and interact with each other to satisfy all the business processes. Following frameworks are evolved to address the requirements of flexibility, enhanceability and scalability of business requirements.

1. **Product Framework:** Entry and Exit capacities are abstracted as products and the product framework addresses the capacity auction/sale process. The Product Framework consists of the business components Product Definition, Product & Price Info, Publish, Bid Capture, Deal Management, Capacity Trading and Capacity Constraing Management.
2. **Energy Balancing Framework:** Energy Balancing processes are divided into various business components and the interaction between these business componens is abstracted into a standard framework. These business components are Meter Details, Nominations, Gas Trade Registration, Measurements, Allocations and Demand Attribution.
3. **Invoicing Framework:** To de-couple business operational processes and invoicing processes, a common and standard Invoicing Framework is adopted which will address invoicing of Product (Entry/Exit Capacity) and Energy Balancing. These business components are Charge Calculation, Cost Sharing, Costs&Incentives, Indebtedness and Invoice Delivery.
4. **Common Application Framework:** To address the common business processes of Capacity and Energy Balacing, a common framework is adopted which consists of Security and Contract Management business processes.

​

**TECHNICAL FRAMEWORK**

To address the business expectations from the GEMINI system, an Open and Industry Standard framework, J2EE, is adopted. And the application development methodology is based on Rational Unfied Process.

1. **Infrastructure:** Application Server: Oracle 9iAS Web Server: Apache Security: Siteminder Database: Oracle 9i OS: HP Unix

​

**INTERFACES**

GEMINI needs to interact with other Transco systems for transmitting and receiving data. These systems are Ulysses, NT&T MIS, CRAM, SC 95, CSEPS, INV 95, Sites&Meters and Unique Sites.

​

**USERS**

GEMINI is accessed by two sets of users, Transco Users and Business Associates. Transco Users belong to the NT&T and Billing divisions and Business Associates are Shippers, Market Operators, CVA(Claims Validation Agents), Storage Operators and InterConnector Agents. Internal users access the system through the Transco Intranet and Business Associates access the system through Intranet or Internet. Access authorisation, authentication and personalisation is dealt by Siteminder suite of products.

National Grid Transco plc (NGT) in the UK owns and operates the high-voltage electricity transmission network in England and Wales, and Britain's natural gas transportation system. In the US, NGT is one of the top ten electricity companies, with the largest electricity transmission and distribution network in the New England/New York region.Transco, one of the business lines of NGT, is the owner, operator and developer of the majority of UK’s gas transportation system. Its network supplies over 40% of UK’s energy needs and even more in winter to 21 million industrial, commercial and domestic consumers.National Transmission and Trading (NT&T), Transco's department, manages and controls the physical and commercial aspects of the gas transmission system with a high speed network made up of around 175,000 miles of pipeline.**NT&T’s primary responsibilities include**

1. Operating the network to deliver gas
2. Managing commercial activities associated with gas transmission
3. Providing the associated primary data for Transco’s billing process
4. Maintaining the physical balance of the system by buying or selling gas to counter daily supply and demand mismatches.

Besides a number of disparate bespoke solutions and spreadsheets, NGT's departments and external users such as Shippers and Market Operators use 2 critical systems, one on mainframe and another on Oracle platform, for managing commercial operations. 

NGT made a decision to replace these systems faced with the following key challenges

- Legacy systems posing high risks
- Regulator enforcing changes to be implemented in quick time
- Stakeholders and users expecting efficient systems

**While they were clear of the 'Why' & 'Where To', they needed a partner to define the 'What' & 'How To' (achieve the business goals with technology solutions).**
b.tp: Replace systems for two critical operations - capacity auctions and energy balancing

b.t: dfasdfaa

identifiers.casName: Capacity auctions & energy balancing systems replacement for a utilities company
identifiers.name: Results

b.t: Natural gas is fundamental to our way of life - we use it for cooking, heating, electricity and power. Over 90% of the natural gas used in Queensland comes from coal seams, but how is it formed and how is it produced? Take a look at how we go about developing our coal seam gas resources safely and sustainably, as we build a new industry that will power the Queensland economy for many years to come.

AT Link supports decision making for Energy Balancing, Exit capacity booking, Exit capacity Trading and Exit Capacity Invoicing. It interacts with various systems like SC 95, CSEPs, S & M, MO systems and Inv’95. AT Link generates Exit Capacity Invoices and Energy Balancing Invoices. AT Link is extensively used by Shippers, CVA, MO, Inter connector Agent and Storage operator in addition to System Operation and Billing users of Transco.
b.tp: AT Link - System for Energy Balancing

b.t: RGTA supports Entry Capacity Auctions, Capacity Constraint management, Entry Capacity Trade registration and produces Entry Capacity Invoices. It Interacts with CRAM for daily Auction capacity details and sends Invoices to Inv 95 systems, which in turn delivers the invoices to the Shippers. It has an interface to AT Link for Allocation details, which is used, in Invoicing.

**BUSINESS PROCESSES**

Gemini deals with the commercial operations of two important areas, Capacity and Energy Balancing of NT&T business operations. Business processes related to Capacity are Entry Capacity Auctions, Exit Capacity Booking, Capacity Constraint management, Capacity Trading and Capacity Invoicing. Business processes related to Energy are Decision making for Energy Balancing and Energy Balance Invoicing.

1. **Entry Capacity Auctions:** Entry Capacity is bought by the Shippers in the form of Firm or Interruptible capacity through Auction process. These Auctions are of various types like Short Term, Long Term or Buy-back.
2. **Exit Capacity Booking:** Exit Capacity is bought by the Shippers through direct booking of capacity.
3. **Capacity Trading:** Entry and Exit Capacity is traded among Shippers and the corresponding trade details are registered.
4. **Capacity Constraint Management:** In the event that the Sippers’ capacity requirements are not met, NT&T can apply constraints and remove all or part of Shipper allotments in accordance with the Shipper Contracts
5. **Capacity Invoicing:** Invoices are sent to the Shippers monthly according to the Entry and Exit Capacity allotments
6. **Energy Balancing:** Gas Balancing is key to the safe operation of transimission network. Shippers provide intended gas flow data (Nominations) at Input and Output points for Transco to plan the balancing operations of the transimission network. Once the gas is transmitted for the Shippers, balances are calculated for each shipper as the difference in the inputs and ourputs into/from the National Transmission System (NTS).
7. **Energy Balance Invoicing:** Invoices are sent to the Shippers based on the imbalances created in the network and based on the scheduling operations of the network.

​

**APPLICATION FRAMEWORKS**

“Capacity” and “Energy Balancing” business processes are grouped into logical business groups and abstracted as various Business Components, which can exist as indepent units and interact with each other to satisfy all the business processes. Following frameworks are evolved to address the requirements of flexibility, enhanceability and scalability of business requirements.

1. **Product Framework:** Entry and Exit capacities are abstracted as products and the product framework addresses the capacity auction/sale process. The Product Framework consists of the business components Product Definition, Product & Price Info, Publish, Bid Capture, Deal Management, Capacity Trading and Capacity Constraing Management.
2. **Energy Balancing Framework:** Energy Balancing processes are divided into various business components and the interaction between these business componens is abstracted into a standard framework. These business components are Meter Details, Nominations, Gas Trade Registration, Measurements, Allocations and Demand Attribution.
3. **Invoicing Framework:** To de-couple business operational processes and invoicing processes, a common and standard Invoicing Framework is adopted which will address invoicing of Product (Entry/Exit Capacity) and Energy Balancing. These business components are Charge Calculation, Cost Sharing, Costs&Incentives, Indebtedness and Invoice Delivery.
4. **Common Application Framework:** To address the common business processes of Capacity and Energy Balacing, a common framework is adopted which consists of Security and Contract Management business processes.

​

**TECHNICAL FRAMEWORK**

To address the business expectations from the GEMINI system, an Open and Industry Standard framework, J2EE, is adopted. And the application development methodology is based on Rational Unfied Process.

1. **Infrastructure:** Application Server: Oracle 9iAS Web Server: Apache Security: Siteminder Database: Oracle 9i OS: HP Unix

​

**INTERFACES**

GEMINI needs to interact with other Transco systems for transmitting and receiving data. These systems are Ulysses, NT&T MIS, CRAM, SC 95, CSEPS, INV 95, Sites&Meters and Unique Sites.

​

**USERS**

GEMINI is accessed by two sets of users, Transco Users and Business Associates. Transco Users belong to the NT&T and Billing divisions and Business Associates are Shippers, Market Operators, CVA(Claims Validation Agents), Storage Operators and InterConnector Agents. Internal users access the system through the Transco Intranet and Business Associates access the system through Intranet or Internet. Access authorisation, authentication and personalisation is dealt by Siteminder suite of products.

identifiers.desc:
**Nations start new eras with epic revolutions. Companies are not different, they too start new eras with epic programmes. **As with the nations, a single purpose of better future drives companies to take on massive initiatives involving 100s of people. This is the story of our client, National Grid Transco (NGT) who serves 40% of the UK’s energy needs piping natural gas for 21 million industrial, commercial and domestic consumers. 

Faced with the challenges of

- Legacy systems posing high risks
- Regulator enforcing quick changes
- Users expecting efficient systems

NGT made a decision to replace systems that support 2 critical functions of commercial operations- capacity auctioning and energy balancing. **While they were clear of the 'Why' & 'Where To', they needed a partner to define the 'What' & 'How To' (achieve the business goals with technology solutions). **

Wipro, one of the NGT's service providers with an 'emerging player' tag, joined the team of National Transmission and Trading (NT&T) division to start the 3+ year epic of Gemini (code named to represent 2 key business functions) from feasibility analysis to development and, periodic roll-out of over 15 sub-systems (2 sub-systems every 6 months). Together they equipped NGT to start the new era with

1. **Flexibility and Compliance:** Systems built on the ethos of component based design and configurable frameworks helped to reduce time of performing operations and time of implementing regulatory changes (e.g. new auctions implementation, billing rule changes etc.).
2. **Scalable Infrastructure:** OS & database servers deployment design helped to increase the system availability and security (e.g. redundant set-ups across geos, multi-level security)
3. **Stakeholder & User satisfaction:** Focus on user interface and inter and intra application interfaces served the variety of needs of the users (e.g. Shipper APIs, NGT systems integration, Goal based UI etc.)

More importantly, this success also laid a new foundation for the engagement between Wipro and NGT - **a shared vision of helping business with technology solutions and, a culture of persistence and innovation solving complex execution challenges**

Overhaul of technology systems & processes transforms the business of an online gifting brand.

f.t:
e-Commerce companies are heavily dependent on robust systems that are scalable. Order fulfillment is all the more crucial for our customer ([Giftcertificates.com](https://www.giftcertificates.com/)), who is into online gifting solutions characterized by seasonal demand peaks.

As the systems are becoming unstable and unable to support the business and peak demands, we stepped in with an integrated approach that focused on site stabilization and total systems re-architecture using emerging technology solutions. We worked with the business and IT teams and executed the project in 3 streams

1. **Infrastructure:** Immediate peak season support, systems stabilization and infrastructure engineering
2. **Technology:** New technology architecture, application development and phased cut over to new systems
3. **Business Process:** Work flow enhancements and reducing offline steps in order processing

**The result was a sound back-end with scalable & efficient order processing, supporting multiple sales channels and the resultant business growth.**
